nodes.text: K-nearest neighbors (KNN) can be used to accurately predict presence of heart disease from clinical and demographic features
This study applies the KNN algorithm as the primary supervised learning method for heart disease classification

The dataset includes clinical and demographic attributes: age, sex, chest pain type, resting blood pressure, cholesterol, fasting blood sugar, restecg, max heart rate, exercise induced angina, oldpeak, slope, ca, thal, and target label
Preprocessing steps include feature selection and handling imbalanced data using weighting strategies prior to KNN training
KNN hyperparameters and procedure used: K set to 10, modelling repeated three times (repeats = 3), Euclidean distance used to find nearest neighbors
Histogram visualizations were produced for numerical features and analysis showed more male patients diagnosed with heart disease in the dataset
Confusion matrix evaluation of the KNN classifier yielded 38 true positives, 45 true negatives, 10 false positives and 7 false negatives, resulting in overall accuracy of 83%
Model performance metrics reported include sensitivity, specificity, accuracy and area under the ROC curve (AUC-ROC), with the authors stating KNN achieved high accuracy and AUC-ROC values
Feature importance analysis was performed to identify key factors contributing to heart disease risk and to enhance model interpretability
KNN limitations include computational expense during classification, sensitivity to chosen K, and requirement for careful preprocessing (scaling, handling missing data)

Conclusion: KNN is a promising, interpretable non-parametric tool for heart disease risk assessment that can assist early detection and decision making, though it requires proper preprocessing and consideration of computational limitations
